messages: d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:19): hi im running ubuntu 6.06 LTS on IBM X31
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:19): im trying to get wireless to work, i have wireless assisstant installed
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:19): but it always fail trying to connect to an AP, i think im missing driver
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:20): where can i grab the driver?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:20): what kind of card is it?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:20): specifically, you need to find out what chipset
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:20): hmm good call, petium M centrino 1.5Ghz
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:21): let me look on vendor's site
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:21): I think Centrino should "just work"on linux but I'm not sure
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:22): it's uh.. 855pm chipset with Banias CPU
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:23): did you try working with iwconfig
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:24): iwconfig is a tool that controls wireless interfaces in linux via the command line
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): here's hte output
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): lo        no wireless extensions.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): irda0     no wireless extensions.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): ath0      IEEE 802.11  ESSID:""
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): Mode:Managed  Frequency:5.24 GHz  Access Point: Not-Associated
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): Bit Rate:6 Mb/s   Tx-Power:18 dBm   Sensitivity=0/3
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): Retry:off   RTS thr:off   Fragment thr:off
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): Power Management:off
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:24): Link Quality=0/94  Signal level=-95 dBm  Noise level=-95 dBm
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:25): man iwconfig for all the details
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): Rx invalid nwid:0  Rx invalid crypt:0  Rx invalid frag:0
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): Tx excessive retries:0  Invalid misc:0   Missed beacon:0
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:25): Oooh... I should try that.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): eth0      no wireless extensions.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): sit0      no wireless extensions.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): vmnet8    no wireless extensions.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): vmnet1    no wireless extensions.
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:25): you can run sudo iwconfig to set ath0 to the AP's name
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:25): however it says to in the manpage
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:25): but just looking at iwconfig output, does it look like i have the proper driver installed?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:26): it looks like ath0 should be ready to configure to an AP
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:26): I should try this, just in case my kernel already supports my wireless adaptor.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:27): ...it's a long shot, but that would save a lot of bother.
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:27): so i should put.. iwconfig ath0 ap <insert ap name here>?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:27): ball: depends on your chipset
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:27): dtsuei: I don't have the manpage in front if me, if it says so
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:27): but you should run it under sudo
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:27): JupiterDuo: Atheros something-or-other I think.
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:28): hmm, I *think* it *might* work.. see if iwconfig picks it up :)
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:28): I think dtsuei's "ath0" might indicate atheros too
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:28): Hello ChakRa
d30d511b32858adc44b54d390500100a (08:29): wut is this atheros thing?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:29): atheros is a type of chipset
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:33): "iwconfig: command not found"
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:34): what distro is it?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:34): you can apt-cache search wireless
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:35): and get wireless-tools or wireless-extensions or something
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:35): (ubuntu/debian)
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:39): Yellow Dog Linux
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:39): oh, hmm
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:39): yeah, get some wireless tools package
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:40): Ah shit.  yum didn't work :-(
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:45): Linux hates me.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (08:45): me too
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (08:45): its a hater
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:46): yeah linux can be tough
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:49): I can't even seem to download the kernel source.
a20c00215ff91bf327808fcf6d1b00bc (08:50): www,kernel.org
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:51): ball: you mean thru yum
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:52): JupiterDuo: I read somewhere that 'yum' was the way to do it.  I'm flailing, this is all so alien to me.
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:52): did you do yum as root or with sudo?
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:52): I was su'd to root
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:52): have you got a netowrk connection?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:53): got a working conf file with sources
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:53): No idea what that means.
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:54): like, the file where it tells yum where to find where it downloads stuff from
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:54): Oh crap.  I don't know.  :-(
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:55): Would that be in /etc somewhere?
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:56): probably
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:56): I have /etc/yum.conf
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (08:56): hello PixieW1ng
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (08:56): yeah, see in there

dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (09:00): hmm, backup... see if you can visit a website
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (09:00): make sure your net conection is working
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:01): Yes, I can use the Web.
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (09:01): I dono wha't sup with yum tho :(
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (09:01): but good luck with all the linux sutff
dfaed3d0eb0bb0e96b26add5a344e5ee (09:02): g'nite
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:02): Thanks JupiterDuo
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:03): Hello kennyt
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:09): hello Eggplant, Cowclops
edd5cc28df2a1432c3bd47cbc6fd3403 (09:13): ball hows it going?
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:14): variable_office: it was going fine until I tried to add a wireless adaptor to my old iBook
edd5cc28df2a1432c3bd47cbc6fd3403 (09:14): ahh, i dont screw with macs
edd5cc28df2a1432c3bd47cbc6fd3403 (09:14): too foreign for my linux and windows accustomed self
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:15): This one has linux on it, but Linux is alien to me
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:15): (I'm used to NetBSD)
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:15): but NetBSD won't run on this old iBook
edd5cc28df2a1432c3bd47cbc6fd3403 (09:15): ah, too bad

592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:16): Agreed, with NetBSD if I can't get something working, the mailing list usually has helpful people who can fix it or at least point me in the right direction.  With Linux I'm pretty much out on my own.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:16): ...and even basic unix things are missing.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:17): ...such as "cu".
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:18): I just want to get the minimum stuff running so that I can connect to a decent NetBSD host, preferrably over 802.11b
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:19): Hello TankEnMate
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:19): ...then I can forget about Linux and just keep working.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:20): (use it like an X terminal)
edd5cc28df2a1432c3bd47cbc6fd3403 (09:20): ya, for me and linux if it isnt detected at install i dont know how to get the hardware running
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:21): variable_office: that's the problem I face.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:21): Yellow Dog Linux knows nothing about the Linksys WUSB11
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:21): ...so I'm screwed.
592418d171424c8cbfdcdf34eaf7f587 (09:21): In NetBSD I could just recompile the kernel with drivers and off it goes.
